docs.title: Xtyle CSS
docs.text: Welcome to Xtyle CSS, a lightweight utility-first CSS framework designed to be colorless and component-less. Xtyle CSS provides a comprehensive set of atomic CSS classes with intuitive abbreviated naming patterns.

docs.title: CDN
docs.text: <link rel="stylesheet" href="https://unpkg.com/xtyle-css@latest" />

docs.title: NPM
docs.text: npm install xtyle-css

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Lightweight: Only 28kb minified (5kb gzipped)
  • Intuitive: Simple abbreviated class names for rapid styling
  • Standalone: No external dependencies
  • Flexible: Design components by combining utility classes
  • Responsive: Built-in responsive grid system

Core Utilities

d | m | p | t | b | s | o | e | row | col | g

docs.title: Utils
docs.text: Key Description d Display m Margin (Spacing) p Padding (Spacing) t Text b Borders s Shadows o Overflow e Extras row Row (Rows & Columns) col Column (Rows & Columns) g Gap (Rows & Columns)

docs.title: Borders
docs.text: Border utilities provide easy control over border appearance, width, style, and radius.

docs.title: Usage Pattern
docs.text:
Border utilities follow the pattern b{type}-{value}

Prefix Description Options bw Border Width 0 to 5 (increasing thickness) bs Border Style dotted, dashed, solid br Border Radius 0 to 4 (increasing radius), 100p (circular), pill (rounded), directional bd Border Display a (all), b (bottom), t (top), r (right), l (left), or with n prefix

docs.title: Direction Abbreviations
docs.text:
Xtyle CSS uses consistent abbreviations for directions:

  • a - All sides
  • t - Top side
  • r - Right side
  • b - Bottom side
  • l - Left side

docs.title: No-Border Utilities
docs.text:
Adding n prefix to border display removes borders:

  • bd-n - No border on any side
  • bd-nt - No border on top
  • bd-nr - No border on right
  • bd-nb - No border on bottom
  • bd-nl - No border on left

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
<!-- Border width and style -->
<div class="bd-a bw-2 bs-solid">Box with medium-thick solid border</div>

<!-- Border style only -->
<div class="bd-a bs-dotted">Box with dotted border</div>

<!-- Pill-shaped element -->
<div class="bd-a br-pill bs-solid">Pill-shaped border</div>

<!-- Mixed border styles -->
<div class="bd-t bd-b bw-1 bs-dashed">Dashed top and bottom borders</div>

<!-- Removing specific borders -->
<div class="bd-a bd-nt bs-solid">Borders on all sides except top</div>

<!-- Border radius on specific corners -->
<div class="br-t bs-solid bd-a">Rounded top corners only</div>

docs.title: Border Width
docs.text: • bw-0, bw-1, bw-2, bw-3, bw-4, bw-5

docs.title: Border Style
docs.text: • bs-dotted, bs-dashed, bs-solid

docs.title: Border Radius
docs.text:
• Size: br-0, br-1, br-2, br-3, br-4
  • Special: br-100p (circle), br-pill (rounded pill)
  • Directional: br-t, br-r, br-b, br-l

docs.title: Border Display
docs.text:
• Show: bd-a, bd-t, bd-r, bd-b, bd-l
  • Hide: bd-n, bd-nt, bd-nr, bd-nb, bd-nl

docs.title: Display and Alignment
docs.text: The display utilities control how elements are rendered on the page and how they're aligned within flex containers.

docs.title: Display Types
docs.text:
Use the pattern d-{type} to control element display types:

Class CSS Applied d-b display: block d-ib display: inline-block d-f display: flex d-if display: inline-flex d-n display: none !important d-hide visibility: hidden !important

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
<div class="d-b">Display: Block</div>
<div class="d-ib">Display: Inline-Block</div>
<div class="d-f">Display: Flex</div>
<div class="d-if">Display: Inline-Flex</div>
<div class="d-n">Display: None (Hidden)</div>
<div class="d-hide">Visibility: Hidden (Space reserved)</div>

docs.title: Positioning
docs.text:
Use the pattern dp-{position} to control element positioning:

Class CSS Applied dp-r position: relative dp-a position: absolute dp-s position: sticky dp-f position: fixed

docs.title: Flex Utilities
docs.text: Comprehensive utilities for working with flexbox layouts.

docs.title: Alignment
docs.text:
Use these patterns to control flex item alignment: - dy-{value} for vertical alignment (align-items) - dx-{value} for horizontal alignment (justify-content)

Class Description CSS Applied dy-fs Align items flex-start align-items: flex-start dy-fe Align items flex-end align-items: flex-end dy-ce Align items center align-items: center dy-st Align items stretch align-items: stretch dx-fs Justify content flex-start justify-content: flex-start dx-fe Justify content flex-end justify-content: flex-end dx-ce Justify content center justify-content: center dx-sb Justify content space-between justify-content: space-between dx-sa Justify content space-around justify-content: space-around dx-se Justify content space-evenly justify-content: space-evenly

docs.title: Example - Alignment
docs.text:
<!-- Centered content horizontally and vertically -->
<div class="d-f dx-ce dy-ce">
  <div>Perfectly centered content</div>
</div>

<!-- Space between items horizontally, align to top -->
<div class="d-f dx-sb dy-fs">
  <div>Left</div>
  <div>Center</div>
  <div>Right</div>
</div>

docs.title: Flex Direction and Growth
docs.text:
Control flex direction and item growth:

Class CSS Applied df-row flex-direction: row df-col flex-direction: column df-fw flex-wrap: wrap df-g0 flex-grow: 0 !important df-g1 flex-grow: 1 !important

df-col

When using df-col (flex-direction: column), a fixed height is required for flex-grow to work properly.

docs.title: Example - Flex Growth and Direction
docs.text:
<!-- Items with varying growth -->
<div class="d-f dx-sb">
  <div class="df-g1">Wide</div>
  <div class="df-g0">Narrow</div>
  <div class="df-g1">Wide</div>
</div>

<!-- Column layout with wrapping -->
<div class="d-f df-col df-fw" style="height: 300px">
  <div>First</div>
  <div class="df-g1">Grows to fill space</div>
  <div>Last</div>
</div>

docs.title: Extras
docs.text: The Extras module provides additional utility classes for common CSS needs that don't fit into other categories.

docs.title: Usage Pattern
docs.text: Extra utilities follow two patterns: - e-{value} for simple properties - e{type}-{value} for grouped properties

docs.title: Available Utilities
docs.text: Class CSS Property Description e-ns user-select: none Prevents text selection e-p cursor: pointer Shows pointer cursor on hover eh-100v height: 100vh Full viewport height eh-100p height: 100% 100% of parent height eh-i height: inherit Inherits height from parent ew-100v width: 100vw Full viewport width ew-100p width: 100% 100% of parent width ew-i width: inherit Inherits width from parent ef-r float: right Floats element to the right ef-l float: left Floats element to the left

docs.title: User Interaction
docs.text:
<!-- Prevent text selection (useful for icons, buttons) -->
<div class="e-ns">
  This text cannot be selected by the user
</div>

<!-- Add pointer cursor to indicate interactivity -->
<div class="e-p">
  This element shows a pointer cursor on hover
</div>

docs.title: Height Control
docs.text:
<!-- Full viewport height container -->
<div class="eh-100v">
  This div is the full height of the viewport
</div>

<!-- Container taking 100% of parent height -->
<div style="height: 300px;">
  <div class="eh-100p" style="background-color: #f0f0f0;">
    This div is exactly as tall as its parent
  </div>
</div>

<!-- Inherit height -->
<div style="height: 200px;">
  <div class="eh-i" style="background-color: #e0e0e0;">
    This inherits the height from parent
  </div>
</div>

docs.title: Width Control
docs.text:
<!-- Full viewport width -->
<div class="ew-100v">
  This spans the entire viewport width
</div>

<!-- 100% parent width -->
<div style="width: 500px;">
  <div class="ew-100p" style="background-color: #f0f0f0;">
    This is 100% of the parent's width (500px)
  </div>
</div>

<!-- Inherit width -->
<div style="width: 400px;">
  <div class="ew-i" style="background-color: #e0e0e0;">
    This inherits width from parent
  </div>
</div>

docs.title: Float Layout
docs.text:
<!-- Basic float example -->
<div style="background-color: #f5f5f5; padding: 10px; overflow: auto;">
  <div class="ef-l" style="background-color: #ddd; padding: 10px;">
    Floated left
  </div>
  <div class="ef-r" style="background-color: #ddd; padding: 10px;">
    Floated right
  </div>
</div>

<!-- Using float for layout -->
<div style="overflow: auto; margin-top: 20px;">
  <img src="https://via.placeholder.com/100" class="ef-l" style="margin-right: 10px;">
  <p>This text wraps around the left-floated image. In modern layouts, 
     consider using flexbox or grid instead of floats, but floats remain
     useful for text-wrapping around images.</p>
</div>

docs.title: Common Use Cases
docs.text:
• Use e-ns for buttons, icons, and interactive elements to prevent accidental text selection
  • Use e-p for clickable elements that don't look like traditional links or buttons
  • Use height/width utilities (eh-*, ew-*) for quick layout adjustments
  • Use float utilities (ef-*) when you need text to wrap around images or for simple layouts

docs.title: Overflow
docs.text: Overflow utilities control how content behaves when it exceeds its container's dimensions.

docs.title: Usage Pattern
docs.text:
Overflow utilities follow the pattern o{axis}-{behavior}

  • Axis: y (vertical) or x (horizontal)
  • Behavior: a (auto) or h (hidden)

docs.title: Overflow Options
docs.text: Class CSS Applied Description oy-a overflow-y: auto Adds scrollbar on Y-axis only when needed oy-h overflow-y: hidden Hides content that overflows vertically ox-a overflow-x: auto Adds scrollbar on X-axis only when needed ox-h overflow-x: hidden Hides content that overflows horizontally

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
<!-- Fixed height container with vertical scrolling -->
<div class="oy-a" style="height: 200px; width: 300px; border: 1px solid #ccc; padding: 10px;">
  <h3>Scrollable Content</h3>
  <p>This content will scroll vertically when it exceeds the container height.</p>
  <p>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Nullam euismod, 
     nisi vel consectetur euismod, nisi nisl consectetur nisi, euismod nisl
     nisi vel consectetur euismod, nisi nisl consectetur nisi, euismod nisl
     nisi vel consectetur euismod, nisi nisl consectetur nisi, euismod nisl.</p>
  <p>Additional content to demonstrate scrolling behavior...</p>
</div>

<!-- Fixed width container with horizontal scrolling -->
<div class="ox-a" style="width: 300px; border: 1px solid #ccc; margin-top: 20px;">
  <div style="width: 600px; padding: 10px;">
    <h3>Horizontally Scrollable Content</h3>
    <p>This content will scroll horizontally because it's wider than its container.</p>
  </div>
</div>

<!-- Container that hides overflow -->
<div class="oy-h" style="height: 100px; width: 300px; border: 1px solid #ccc; margin-top: 20px; padding: 10px;">
  <h3>Hidden Overflow</h3>
  <p>This content is cut off when it exceeds the container's height.</p>
  <p>Additional content that will be hidden...</p>
</div>

docs.title: Scrollable Areas
docs.text:
Create scrollable areas for content without expanding the page layout:

<!-- Scrollable table container -->
<div class="oy-a" style="max-height: 300px;">
  <table>
    <!-- Table content -->
  </table>
</div>

<!-- Scrollable sidebar -->
<aside class="oy-a" style="height: 100vh;">
  <!-- Sidebar content -->
</aside>

docs.title: Preventing Layout Shifts
docs.text:
Prevent unwanted layout shifts due to content size changes:

<!-- Fixed size card with scrollable content area -->
<div class="card" style="height: 400px;">
  <div class="card-header">Card Title</div>
  <div class="card-body oy-a" style="height: calc(400px - 60px);">
    <!-- Variable height content -->
  </div>
</div>

docs.title: Mobile-Friendly Tables
docs.text:
Make data tables responsive by allowing horizontal scrolling:

<!-- Responsive table container -->
<div class="ox-a">
  <table style="min-width: 600px;">
    <!-- Wide table content -->
  </table>
</div>

docs.title: Grid System
docs.text: Xtyle CSS provides a flexible grid system based on CSS Grid and Flexbox that simplifies responsive layouts.

docs.title: Basic Grid Structure
docs.text: A grid consists of: 1. A container with the row class 2. Child elements with the col class 3. Optional gap utilities (gx-* and gy-*) for spacing

docs.title: Row Container
docs.text:
The row class creates a flex container that wraps its children and provides the foundation for the grid system.

<div class="row">
  <!-- Columns go here -->
</div>

docs.title: Gap Utilities
docs.text:
Control the spacing between grid items using gap utilities:

Class Pattern CSS Property Available Sizes gx-* column-gap 0 through 16 gy-* row-gap 0 through 16 
<!-- Grid with horizontal gap of 2 units and vertical gap of 3 units -->
<div class="row gx-2 gy-3">
  <!-- Columns -->
</div>

docs.title: Columns and Responsive Breakpoints
docs.text:
Columns automatically adjust based on the available space. Use responsive classes to control column width at different screen sizes:

Prefix Screen Width Example Use Case col-sm Small (max-width: 767px) Mobile phones col-md Medium (min-width: 768px) Tablets col-lg Large (min-width: 992px) Laptops/Desktops col-xl Extra large (min-width: 1200px) Large displays

Column sizes range from 1 to 12, representing the number of columns out of 12 that the element should span.

<!-- This column will be full width on small screens, half width on medium screens, 
     and one-third width on large screens -->
<div class="col col-sm-12 col-md-6 col-lg-4">Content</div>

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
Here's a responsive grid with three columns that stack on mobile:

<div class="row gx-4 gy-3">
  <!-- On mobile: 100% width, On tablet: 50% width, On desktop: 33.33% width -->
  <div class="col col-sm-12 col-md-6 col-lg-4">
    <div class="p-3" style="background-color: #f0f0f0; border-radius: 4px;">
      <h3>First Column</h3>
      <p>This column adjusts its width based on screen size.</p>
    </div>
  </div>

  <div class="col col-sm-12 col-md-6 col-lg-4">
    <div class="p-3" style="background-color: #f0f0f0; border-radius: 4px;">
      <h3>Second Column</h3>
      <p>On mobile, these stack vertically. On tablet, they form two columns.</p>
    </div>
  </div>

  <div class="col col-sm-12 col-md-12 col-lg-4">
    <div class="p-3" style="background-color: #f0f0f0; border-radius: 4px;">
      <h3>Third Column</h3>
      <p>On desktop, they form three equal columns.</p>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

docs.title: Asymmetric Layouts
docs.text:
Create uneven column distributions for more diverse layouts:

<div class="row gx-3">
  <!-- Sidebar: 1/4 width on large screens -->
  <div class="col col-sm-12 col-lg-3">
    <div class="p-3" style="background-color: #e0e0e0; height: 300px;">
      Sidebar
    </div>
  </div>

  <!-- Main content: 3/4 width on large screens -->
  <div class="col col-sm-12 col-lg-9">
    <div class="p-3" style="background-color: #f5f5f5; height: 300px;">
      Main Content Area
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

docs.title: Nested Grids
docs.text:
Grids can be nested within columns for more complex layouts:

<div class="row gx-3">
  <div class="col col-md-6">
    <div class="p-3" style="background-color: #e0e0e0;">
      <h3>Main Column</h3>

      <!-- Nested grid -->
      <div class="row gx-2 gy-2">
        <div class="col col-6">Nested Column 1</div>
        <div class="col col-6">Nested Column 2</div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

  <div class="col col-md-6">
    <div class="p-3" style="background-color: #e0e0e0;">
      Second Main Column
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

docs.title: Auto-Width Columns
docs.text:
Omit the column width specifications to let columns automatically share the available space:

<div class="row">
  <div class="col">Equal width</div>
  <div class="col">Equal width</div>
  <div class="col">Equal width</div>
</div>

docs.title: Shadows
docs.text: Shadow utilities allow you to add depth and dimension to your elements through directional box shadows.

docs.title: Usage Pattern
docs.text:
Shadow utilities follow the pattern s{side}-{depth}

  • Side: b (bottom), t (top), r (right), or l (left)
  • Depth: Numeric values representing shadow intensity

docs.title: Shadow Options
docs.text: Class Prefix Direction Available Depths Effect sb Bottom shadow 0 to 24 Elevates element above surface st Top shadow 0 to 24 Creates inset or pressed appearance sr Right shadow 0 to 12 Adds depth to the left side sl Left shadow 0 to 12 Adds depth to the right side

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
<!-- Basic shadows with different sides and depths -->
<div class="sb-3 p-3 m-3">Light bottom shadow (elevation 3)</div>
<div class="sb-8 p-3 m-3">Medium bottom shadow (elevation 8)</div>
<div class="sb-16 p-3 m-3">Heavy bottom shadow (elevation 16)</div>

<!-- Combining shadows for more complex effects -->
<div class="sb-6 sr-3 p-3 m-3">Bottom and right shadow</div>

<!-- Card with shadow -->
<div class="sb-4 p-4 m-3" style="width: 300px; border-radius: 4px;">
  <h3 class="ts-3">Card Title</h3>
  <p>This card uses a subtle bottom shadow to create depth.</p>
</div>

<!-- Inset effect with top shadow -->
<div class="st-8 p-4 m-3" style="width: 300px; border-radius: 4px; background: #f5f5f5;">
  <p>This element appears to be pressed into the surface.</p>
</div>

<!-- Button with shadow -->
<button class="sb-3 p-2 px-4 m-3" style="border: none; border-radius: 4px; background: #4285f4; color: white;">
  Elevated Button
</button>

docs.title: Interactive Shadow Example
docs.text:
For interactive elements like buttons, you can use different shadow depths for different states:

<style>
  .btn {
    padding: 10px 20px;
    background: #4285f4;
    color: white;
    border: none;
    border-radius: 4px;
    transition: all 0.2s ease;
  }
  .btn:hover { box-shadow: var(--shadow-bottom-6); }
  .btn:active { box-shadow: var(--shadow-bottom-2); }
</style>

<button class="btn sb-4">Interactive Button</button>

docs.title: Material Design Inspired Elevation
docs.text:
The shadow system is inspired by Material Design's elevation concept, where higher values create more pronounced shadows, simulating greater distance from the surface:

  • Subtle elevation (1-4): For cards, buttons in resting state
  • Medium elevation (5-12): For dropdowns, dialogs, hovered elements
  • High elevation (13-24): For temporary UI like popups, tooltips

docs.title: Implementation Details
docs.text: Each shadow class applies a CSS box-shadow property with appropriate values for offset, blur, spread, and color to create the shadow effect at a specific depth level.

docs.title: Spacing (Margin and Padding)
docs.text: The spacing utilities control the whitespace around and within elements through margin and padding.

docs.title: Usage Pattern
docs.text:
Spacing utilities follow the pattern {type}{direction}-{size}

  • Type: m (margin) or p (padding)
  • Direction: t, r, b, l, x, or y
  • Size: 0 through 24, auto, or n{size} for negative values

docs.title: Margin vs Padding
docs.text: Prefix CSS Property Description m margin Space outside element boundaries p padding Space inside element boundaries

docs.title: Direction Control
docs.text:
Control which sides receive spacing:

Direction Applies To Example t Top only mt-4, pt-2 r Right only mr-3, pr-4 b Bottom only mb-5, pb-3 l Left only ml-2, pl-1 x Left and right sides mx-4, px-auto y Top and bottom sides my-3, py-2 (none) All sides m-4, p-2

docs.title: Size Values
docs.text:
Sizes range from 0 to 24, representing increasing amounts of space:

  • 0 - No space
  • 1-24 - Increasing amounts of space
  • auto - Browser-calculated automatic spacing (margin only)

docs.title: Negative Margins
docs.text:
For negative margins, add n before the size number:

<div class="ml-n3">Pulled 3 units to the left</div>
<div class="mt-n12">Pulled 12 units upward</div>

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
<!-- Basic spacing -->
<div class="m-4">Margin on all sides</div>
<div class="p-4">Padding on all sides</div>

<!-- Directional spacing -->
<div class="mt-4">Margin top only</div>
<div class="px-3">Padding left and right</div>
<div class="my-2">Margin top and bottom</div>

<!-- Negative margins -->
<div class="mt-n4">Negative top margin</div>

<!-- Auto margins (great for centering) -->
<div class="mx-auto" style="width: 200px">Horizontally centered</div>

<!-- Combining margin and padding -->
<div class="m-2 p-4">Margin outside, padding inside</div>

<!-- Responsive layout example -->
<div class="d-f">
  <div class="px-2 py-3">Left column</div>
  <div class="px-2 py-3 ml-4">Right column with left margin</div>
</div>

docs.title: Common Use Cases
docs.text:
• Card spacing: p-4 for internal card padding
  • Content sections: my-5 to separate major sections vertically
  • Grid gutters: px-2 for horizontal spacing between columns
  • Centering blocks: mx-auto with a set width
  • Negative overlaps: mt-n2 to create overlapping elements

docs.title: Typography
docs.text: Typography utilities control text appearance including size, style, decoration, alignment, and text transformation.

docs.title: Usage Pattern
docs.text:
Text utilities follow the pattern t{type}-{value}

Prefix Controls Examples ts Text Size ts-1 (largest) through ts-6 (smallest) td Text Decoration td-b (bold), td-i (italic) tt Text Transform tt-u (uppercase), tt-c (truncate) ta Text Alignment ta-c (center), ta-l (left)

docs.title: Text Size
docs.text:
Font sizes are predefined with CSS variables:

:root {
  --text-size-1: 3rem;      /* ts-1 */
  --text-size-2: 2.25rem;   /* ts-2 */
  --text-size-3: 1.5rem;    /* ts-3 */
  --text-size-4: 1.25rem;   /* ts-4 */
  --text-size-5: 1rem;      /* ts-5 */
  --text-size-6: 0.875rem;  /* ts-6 */
}

docs.title: Example - Text Size
docs.text:
<h1 class="ts-1">Large Heading (3rem)</h1>
<h2 class="ts-2">Medium Heading (2.25rem)</h2>
<h3 class="ts-3">Small Heading (1.5rem)</h3>
<p class="ts-5">Normal paragraph text (1rem)</p>
<p class="ts-6">Small text (0.875rem)</p>

docs.title: Text Decoration
docs.text:
Control font weight, style, and text decorations:

Class Effect CSS Applied td-b Bold text font-weight: bold td-i Italic text font-style: italic td-u Underlined text text-decoration: underline td-s Strikethrough text text-decoration: line-through

docs.title: Example - Text Decoration
docs.text:
<p class="td-b">Bold text</p>
<p class="td-i">Italic text</p>
<p class="td-u">Underlined text</p>
<p class="td-s">Strikethrough text</p>
<p class="td-b td-i">Bold and italic text</p>

docs.title: Text Transform
docs.text:
Control text capitalization and truncation:

Class Effect CSS Applied tt-t Title Case text-transform: capitalize tt-u UPPERCASE text-transform: uppercase tt-l lowercase text-transform: lowercase tt-c Truncate with ... text-overflow: ellipsis; white-space: nowrap; overflow: hidden

docs.title: Example - Text Transform
docs.text:
<p class="tt-t">title case text (first letter of each word capitalized)</p>
<p class="tt-u">uppercase text (all capitals)</p>
<p class="tt-l">LOWERCASE TEXT (all lowercase)</p>
<div style="width: 200px">
  <p class="tt-c">This text will be truncated with an ellipsis when it's too long</p>
</div>

docs.title: Text Alignment
docs.text:
Control horizontal text alignment:

Class Effect CSS Applied ta-l Left-aligned text text-align: left ta-c Centered text text-align: center ta-r Right-aligned text text-align: right

docs.title: Example - Text Alignment
docs.text:
<p class="ta-l">Left-aligned text (default)</p>
<p class="ta-c">Centered text</p>
<p class="ta-r">Right-aligned text</p>

docs.title: Combined Examples
docs.text:
<!-- Heading with multiple text styles -->
<h1 class="ts-2 tt-u ta-c">CENTERED UPPERCASE HEADING</h1>

<!-- Important notice -->
<p class="td-b td-u">Important: Please read carefully!</p>

<!-- Truncated label -->
<div style="width: 150px" class="tt-c td-b">This is a very long text that will be truncated</div>
